definition: public/collectively owned/common/international (e.g. high seas, metric system, calendar)/make public/fair/just/Duke, highest of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/honorable (gentlemen)/father-in-law/male (animal)
section/paragraph/funds/CL:筆|笔[bi3],個|个[ge4]/classifier for versions or models (of a product)

sentences.english: They were embezzling funds right under his nose.
sentences.chinese: 他们就在他眼皮子底下把公款贪污了。

sentences.english: The minister was found to have appropriated government money.
He remembered instances in which defaulters had been captured.
sentences.chinese: 他想起一些盗用公款的罪犯被捉拿归案的例子。

sentences.english: The problem is not simply one of embezzlement and bribery.
sentences.chinese: 问题不仅仅是挪用公款和贪污受贿那么简单。

sentences.english: He rapped the government over the knuckles for wasting public money.
sentences.chinese: 他严厉批评政府浪费公款。

sentences.english: Most embezzlers are found out in the end.
sentences.chinese: 大多数盗用公款的人最后都被发现了。

sentences.english: First section, the abject and target violated by crime of embezzle public funds.
sentences.chinese: 第一部分，关于挪用公款罪侵犯的客体和犯罪对象。

sentences.english: Mr Sengoku was also scathing about Japan’s habit of using public money to rescue bankrupt firms.
sentences.chinese: 由人先生还批评日本用公款救助行将倒闭公司的怪癖。

sentences.english: RA would also mention the name of a bogus firm to cover up the embezzlement.
sentences.chinese: RA同时提到使用一家假公司的名称来掩盖侵吞公款。

sentences.english: They accused him of plundering the public treasury .
Cashier was found guilty of peculation and removed from his post.
sentences.chinese: 出纳员被发现犯了盗用公款罪便被解除了职务。

sentences.english: He built private houses whit public funds. The whole thing smells to high heaven.
sentences.chinese: 他用公款盖房这件事真是腐败透顶。

sentences.english: You're about to be killed for using the government's money, you know.
sentences.chinese: 你很快就要因盗用公款罪而被杀头了，知道吗？

sentences.english: No entity may change public money into individual savings deposit.
sentences.chinese: 任何单位不许将公款转为个人储蓄存款。
他们贪污挪用公款使商行破产了。

definition: supplementary cash reserve/private fund/private hoard/slush fund
to shift (funds)/to (legitimately) take funds set aside for one purpose in order to use them for another/to embezzle/to misappropriate
to use one's position for personal gain (idiom)
to get an advance on one's pay
to exact bribes/to solicit bribes/to demand bribes/to extort
to stuff one's pockets/to take bribes
to be a guest at a dinner party/to be wined and dined (as a bribe)
